title: How to write a well developed narcissistic character - Quora

response.answer_text: Give them pains and gains of being who they are. My two protagonists are both quite arrogant and self-assured. That benefits them in some ways but wounds them in others. My female protagonist begins the first novel with the crystal clear belief that she'll get what she wants: the shock and pain of not getting it sets her back. She has to shape up and deal with the fact that her brilliance doesn't mean the world will bend to her will. And here's the thing; she IS brilliant. The fact that objectively she had earned and was capable of what she wanted is a big sting in the tail. Her development comes from learning to deal with the world as it is, accepting the help of others, and the vulnerability and humility that entails - without damaging her justified confidence in her skills.

Give the character attributes that make them better than other in certain aspects. Then make other characters lack in these attributes. Because of other characters lack in this field you can exploit this to make the character narcissistic. From there you will have a strong character to work with.

My advice would be to read classical novels that have these characters. Brothers Karamazov abounds with these- Dostoevsky ‘wrote the book’ on Narcissism which is an issue for almost every major and minor character. Oscar Wilde also created some great Narcissistic characters- The Picture of Dorian Grey is often cited. Heathcliff in Wuthering Heights Henry Higgins My Fair Lady One writer says Fred Flintstone.
